title: Lambourn Valley Way Walking Route

images.title: Graham Horn / Lambourn Valley Way
images.caption:
Here the way uses the trackbed of the former Lambourn Valley railway that ran from Newbury to Lambourn. Thus, easy level walking.
The railway opened in 1898 and was closed to passenger traffic in 1960. A section between Newbury and Welford remained open for freight traffic to RAF Welford until 1972. Steam railmotors and a GWR diesel railcar were used on the line, as well as steam engines owned by the Lambourn valley Railway, and Great Western Railway standard engines.

images.title: Pam Brophy / Stile on the Lambourn Valley Way at Welford
images.caption: Stile on the Lambourn Valley Way at Welford. The square is largely farmland and Weston Park land.

images.title: Philipjelley, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: River Lambourn, East Garston, Berkshire. The waterway flows through the village, dividing many houses from the main road, so that each has a bridge over the river to the front door. The river is defined as a chalk stream, rising in the Berkshire Downs near its namesake village of Lambourn. It is a tributary of the River Kennet, which is itself a tributary of the River Thames.

images.title: Andrew Smith / Lambourn valley farmland
images.caption: Lambourn valley farmland. Looking across a small valley, an offshoot of the main valley. The western flank has a shallow gradient. The eastern flank, shielded from view, is much steeper and is grassland. Gallops are in the bottom of the valley.

images.title: Andrew Smith / Uffington Down
images.caption: Uffington Down. Here a walker can be seen heading along the bridleway immediately to the south of the Ridgeway. The bridleway is part of the Lambourn Valley Way and is to the left of the fence.

images.title: Andrew Smith / Farmland, Coldborough
images.caption: Farmland, Coldborough. Looking up a small dry valley into the downs above the trail.

images.title: Lambourn Valley Way by Des Blenkinsopp, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: A horse poses for the camera in a farm at Lambourn village

images.title: Des Blenkinsopp / Lambourn High Street
images.caption: High Street, Lambourn. After Newmarket the village is the largest centre of racehorse training in England, and is home to a rehabilitation centre for injured jockeys, an equine hospital, and several leading jockeys and trainers. To the north of the village are the prehistoric Seven Barrows and a nearby long barrow.

description: Travel from Oxfordshire into Berkshire along the Lambourn Valley Way and enjoy woodland, parkland and a series of quaint towns and villages. The walk starts at the Bronze age fort at Uffington Castle and the distinctive prehistoric Uffington White Horse hill figure. From here you head south across the Lambourn Downs before following the River Lambourn through Lambourn, Boxford and Speen before a lovely stretch along the Kennet and Avon Canal takes you into Newbury . Here you could visit Donnington Castle which lies just off the route. The medieval castle is surrounded by attractive farmland and peaceful woodland. It's a nice place to stop for a picnic and learn about the history of the area.
